title: 111_hr4897
content: The Act may be cited as the "Drivers Accelerated Interest Deductibility Act of 2010" or the "Drivers AID Act". Congress acknowledges the importance of a strong automotive industry for the economic health of the United States. Automotive sales have significantly declined since 2008, with annual rates falling below 10,000,000 units. This decline has impacted the financial security of millions of Americans. In 2008, the automotive new vehicle dealers industry in the United States had substantial contributions to the national economy. The average sales revenue for around 20,000 new automobile dealers was $28.8 million, totaling $576 billion for all new-vehicle dealerships. With 1,057,500 employees earning an average of $48,963 per year, generating a national payroll of over $52 billion and millions in tax revenue for State and local governments. The automotive new vehicle dealers industry in the United States had substantial contributions to the national economy in 2008. With an average of 53 employees per dealership earning $48,963 per year, the industry generated a national payroll of over $52 billion. A well-capitalized dealer network is crucial for the success of automobile manufacturers, and reducing the cost of capital for consumers to purchase new vehicles will strengthen the industry and the national economy. The deduction of nonmortgage interest payments, like automobile loan debt, for Federal income tax purposes was available from 1913 until 1986 when Congress ended it with the Tax Reform Act of 1986. This change in tax policy had a positive impact on the automotive industry and the national economy. The Tax Reform Act of 1986 ended the deduction for nonmortgage interest payments, including those for acquiring a passenger car or light truck. The Tax Reform Act of 1986 eliminated the deduction for nonmortgage interest payments, including those for acquiring a passenger car or light truck. Section 163(h) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subparagraph (G) for qualified vehicle interest if the national unemployment rate is not less than 7 percent. The term 'qualified vehicle interest' refers to interest properly chargeable on debt incurred to acquire a qualified vehicle, limited to $5,000 and allocated to a 36-month period. Section 163(h) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subparagraph (G) for qualified vehicle interest if the national unemployment rate is not less than 7 percent. The term 'qualified vehicle interest' refers to interest properly chargeable on debt incurred to acquire a qualified vehicle, limited to $5,000 and allocated to a 36-month period. Only interest on indebtedness allocable to the 36-month period beginning on the date of incurrence may be taken into account. Payment is made under section 1302 of the Consumer Assistance to Recycle and Save Act of 2009 for a motor vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating of 6,000 pounds or less, treated as a passenger automobile or light truck. A motor vehicle is defined as a vehicle primarily for use on public streets with at least 4 wheels. The term 'motor vehicle' refers to a vehicle designed for public road use with at least 4 wheels. Other terms like 'automobile' and 'manufacturer' are defined by the EPA. The average national unemployment rate is calculated based on monthly rates. The amendment allows for a deduction in adjusted gross income for qualified vehicle interest under section 163(h)(5) of the Internal Revenue Code. The effective date for these changes is for vehicles acquired on or after January 1, 2008.
